sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: SAP Cloud Platform is an enterprise Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) offering from SAP, with comprehensive application development services and capabilities. It enables customers to achieve business agility, create a truly integrated and optimized enterprise, and accelerate digital transformation across the business, without the need to invest in and maintain an on-premise infrastructure. However, some customers who could benefit from SAP Cloud Platform want to run cloud services in their own data centers to meet requirements for governance, security, data privacy, IP protection and legal restrictions. This is why SAP offers SAP Cloud Platform, private edition. SAP Cloud Platform, private edition is based on SAP's public cloud offering, but can be deployed on the customer’s premises.

Based on open standards, SAP Cloud Platform offers complete flexibility and control over your choice of clouds, frameworks, and applications. SAP Cloud Platform runs on top of an Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) layer.

This document provides guidance on how to prepare an IaaS environment for SAP Cloud Platform. It includes an overview of the architecture and key aspects of the IaaS platform based on SUSE products and is specifically designed for SAP Cloud Platform.

sect1.title: IaaS Architecture for SAP Cloud Platform
sect1.para: SAP Cloud Platform is built to fulfill the requirements of a modern future-proof data center where applications are created on a container base. This enables an agile operation according to a DevOps approach. SAP Cloud Platform runs on top of an IaaS layer, which provides all needed physical resources (compute, storage and networking).
The IaaS platform is based on SUSE OpenStack Cloud and SUSE Enterprise Storage, and is specifically designed and configured for SAP Cloud Platform.

SAP Cloud Platform uses cloud-native workloads. The underlying IaaS needs to be optimized for these workloads. This optimization is the result of a long-term collaboration of SAP and SUSE. It provides the right products and the right configuration for a reliable SAP Cloud Platform. The IaaS platform is based on commodity x86 rack servers for cost-efficiency and to avoid vendor lock-in.

sect2.title: High-level Architecture
sect2.para: A key design aspect for scalability and high availability is that, regardless of the size of a production landscape, all components are evenly distributed across three different independent areas. One single area can fail without an impact to the availability of a service. This concept is called 'Failure Domain' (FD), and is described in detail in the chapter
SAP Cloud Platform is based on the Scale-Out approach, see also .
SAP Cloud Platform consists of three different layers.
Application Layer: This is the layer where the applications, services and the platform (for example CloudFoundry) for providing these services run.
Control Layer: These are the services needed to provide the IaaS. They are invisible for the applications.
Storage Layer: This is where the persistent data is stored.
Each layer has specific requirements to ensure its own availability, and needs to be distributed across all Failure Domains.

sect2.title: Failure Domains
sect2.para: Failure Domains are physical demarcations each with its own independent fire compartment, power supply and networking infrastructure.
The infrastructure for SAP Cloud Platform needs to be distributed over three Failure Domains. This ensures that one single Failure Domain can fail without impacting the availability of a service.

sect2.title: High Availability
sect2.para: High availability is delivered on multiple levels in the IaaS stack. The design principle is to ensure fault isolation so that an error in a Failure Domain does not affect the global service. The availability of each respective layer is realized in different ways.

Application Layer: SAP Cloud Platform ensures that the service is available (including restarting or relocating). It chooses the right available resources for these services. The availability of an application is the responsibility of SAP Cloud Platform (PaaS). This can be archived by a "cloud-native" design of the application itself.

Control Layer: To use SAP Cloud Platform in a production environment, it is mandatory to ensure its high availability. These control layer components (for example message broker, databases and API services) are distributed across all three Failure Domains and are clustered with SUSE Linux Enterprise High Availability Extension.

Storage Layer: SUSE Enterprise Storage has built-in high availability by design, and is using three replicas distributed across all three Failure Domains. SUSE Enterprise Storage provides self-healing and auto balancing features.
The network design needs to ensure that the failure of a network component will not result in the failure of the entire network, individual services or individual applications.

sect2.title: Scalability
sect2.para: In the SAP Cloud Platform the scale-out principle is used. Additional servers are added to expand the environment.
Application Layer: Additional servers will be added to each FD symmetrically. Ideally, all newly-added servers are identical and have the same configuration.
Control Layer: The administrative servers are sufficiently sized so that they do not need to be extended.
Storage Layer: Additional servers will be added to each FD symmetrically. Ideally, all newly-added servers are identical and have the same configuration.

sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: Specific infrastructure and hardware requirements must be met for SAP Cloud Platform. The size depends on the application workload.

sect2.title: Production Environment
sect2.para: To build your own SAP Cloud Platform, private edition you need the following minimum resources:

listitem.para: Each server requires at least 2x50Gbit/s and 1x10Gbit/s network connections.
Each of the OSI layer 2 networks must be distributed over all Failure Domains
The network backbone design must support this network load, including future growth
Top of Rack switches in a Leaf-Spine architecture are recommended
Commodity servers of the same type (SUSE YES Certified) with at least 2 sockets and 512 GB RAM
SUSE OpenStack Cloud and SUSE Enterprise Storage subscriptions

sect2.title: Proof of Concept/Test Environment
sect2.para: Most customer projects start evaluation of SAP Cloud Platform with a Proof of Concept (PoC). If you plan to use the PoC environment later in production, it must follow the guidelines of a production environment, otherwise migration is not possible.
The requirements for a PoC are smaller:

listitem.para: Each server requires at least 10 Gbit/s network bandwidth
Commodity servers of the same type (SUSE YES Certified).
1000 CPU-threads, 6 TB RAM and 40 TB raw storage for an initial PoC SAP Cloud Platform Configuration
SUSE OpenStack Cloud and SUSE Enterprise Storage subscriptions
